ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to improve my Chinese grammar, speaking, and reading.
Commonly used grammar structures, illness, travel, and school-related vocabulary. Much more speaking and listening practice, opportunities to write short essays and present to classmates.
Intermediate Chinese vocabulary, grammar structures, and speaking.
I improved on my reading, listening, and speaking skills.

I learned how to be more fluid and confident and speaking. Also, the immersive classroom helped me understand spoken Chinese much better. Though it was intimidating at first to have a Chinese-only classroom, it was very helpful in learning. Everyone was so kind that it made the class very fun.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish there were just a final exam and not also a final project. The online dictation as opposed to daily dictation was a nice change from Beginner Chinese. Sometimes there was a bit of miscommunication between the course head and professors, so I would hope that would be more organized too.
I appreciate how structured this course is and found the activities to be not only engaging but also useful in advancing my understanding of our lessons.
Teachers are extremely nice and helpful and assignments force you to learn the material thoroughly

The course was well-organized and I appreciated how a schedule of assignments was given at the beginning of the year. It was a lot of work, however, so it wasnt very easy to get ahead. But knowing the schedule ahead of time was helpful in planning for test studying etc. there were some assignments that were really hard such as listening to a video and answering a timed quiz about it. These were really hard when the person spoke quickly because unless you are able to understand spoken Mandarin easily you have to go back many times to make sure you understand the material. It would be better to make the quiz not timed because this was really scary and the time added a lot of pressure to fully understand the first time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It is a great way to continue improving your Chinese.

Yes, learning Chinese is very rewarding, and CHNS 130 has many fun activities too! For example, during one week, we watched a Chinese movie for 2 days and during another day, we went to the Hong Kong Market on Whitney to buy Chinese-style snacks. The class had a lot of fun activities that made my experience with CHNS 130 very enjoyable.

L3 is a great way to fast-track your grammar and speaking skills as well as your ability to read longer, more complex passages in Chinese. We also learn about modern Chinese culture and the differences between the American and Chinese education systems.
Yes, as long as you are prepared for the high workload, you really learn a lot of Chinese
I would recommend this course. I really enjoyed the classes, and I definitely learned a lot.
if the Chinese department reduces the number of students it has per class, then yes. Overall, it is a great course.

I would recommend this course to anyone I retested in learning mandarin and willing to put in a lot of work. The curriculum moved quickly and it required a lot of practice to keep up. The teachers were very encouraging and understanding, which made the work worth it. The class was a lot of fun, especially the final project!
